subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
In the oracle bone script, it was an {{liushu|ic|nocap=1}}: 2 or 4 {{zh-l|*屮|grass}} + {{zh-l|*日|sun}} + {{zh-l|*月|moon}} – the sun rising above the grass while the waning moon is still in the sky – the morning.

In the bronze script, it was a compound of {{zh-l|*𠦝}} and a pictograph of a river ({{zh-l|*川}} or {{zh-l|*水}}) – this is the original form of {{och-l|潮|tide}}. The river glyph may be a corruption of {{zh-l|*月}} due to association with tides. {{zh-ref|Chi (2010)}} considers such forms to be {{liushu|psc|nocap=1|adj=1}}, where {{zh-l|*𠦝}} is the abbreviated form of the phonetic {{och-l|朝}}. In the late Western Zhou forms, {{zh-l|*𠦝}} is corrupted into {{zh-l|*車}}.

In the stone drum inscriptions ({{w2|zh|石鼓文}}), {{zh-l|*㫃}} is added (attached to {{zh-l|*車}}), and the river glyph is replaced with {{och-l|舟}}, which acts as a phonetic component; the small seal script likely inherits from this form. ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' interprets the fused component of {{zh-l|*𠦝}} and {{zh-l|*㫃}} as a semantic component {{zh-l|*倝|dawn}}. The {{zh-l|*舟}} component is also seen in the {{w|bamboo and wooden slips}} of the {{w|Warring States period}}.

In the clerical script, {{zh-l|*舟}} is reverted to {{zh-l|*月}}; it is unclear whether this is a remnant from {{zh-l|*月}} in the oracle bone script or a corruption of {{zh-l|*舟}} (as in {{zh-l|*朕}} < {{zh-l|*𦩎}}). The current form is essentially inherited from the clerical script.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
“Morning” > “perform the morning ceremony” > “to go/come to court; to have an audience”. Derivative: {{och-l|潮|morning tide}}.

Perhaps related to {{cog|th|เพรา||morning}} ({{zh-ref|Manomaivibool, 1975}}).
